channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: In China, Desperate Patients Smuggle Drugs. Or Make Their Own.
item.media:description: Zhang Zhejun, a salesmen in Hebei, China, made his own drugs from ingredients purchased online to give to his mother, who suffered from lung cancer.
item.description: Despite health insurance, terminally ill patients have to hunt around the world and on the internet for ways to stay alive.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: Taliban Slaughter Elite Afghan Troops, and a ‘Safe’ District Is Falling
item.media:description: The bodies of 20 commandos were lined up outside the governor’s office in Sang-e-Masha, Afghanistan, on Sunday. Their company was almost entirely destroyed fighting the Taliban.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: Times journalists traveled to the site of a Taliban assault. Instead of a fierce stand by government commandos, they found a massacre of those American-trained troops.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Saudis Close to Crown Prince Discussed Killing Other Enemies a Year Before Khashoggi’s Death
item.media:description: Top Saudi officials considered using private companies to assassinate political enemies at a time when Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was consolidating power.
item.description: During discussions in Riyadh in 2017, Saudi intelligence officials discussed hiring private companies to kill the head of Iran’s Quds force and other Iranian operatives.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI, RONEN BERGMAN and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Trump’s Nationalism, Rebuked at World War I Ceremony, Is Reshaping Much of Europe
item.media:description: President Trump arriving at Suresnes American Cemetery outside Paris on Sunday as part of the commemoration the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: As world leaders marked the 100th anniversary of the Great War’s end, President Emmanuel Macron of France declared that “nationalism is a betrayal of patriotism.”
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Deadly Gaza Raid by Israel Threatens Nascent Cease-Fire
item.media:description: A destroyed building on Monday in Khan Yunis, in southern Gaza, after an Israeli airstrike over the weekend.
item.description: A covert mission apparently went awry on Sunday, leaving an Israeli lieutenant colonel and at least seven Palestinians dead and setting off a flurry of rocket fire and airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: In North Korea, Missile Bases Suggest a Great Deception
item.media:description: A satellite image of a secret North Korean ballistic missile base. The North has offered to dismantle a different major missile launching site while continuing to make improvements at more than a dozen others.
item.description: President Trump says the nuclear threat from North Korea is over. New satellite images of 16 hidden ballistic missile bases suggest that it has worsened since his summit meeting.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies

item.title: APEC Host Country Has Few Good Roads, but It Has Maseratis
item.media:description: A banner for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting being held this week in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea. The country is by far the poorest of APEC’s 21 member economies.
item.description: The Pacific nation of Papua New Guinea is in the global spotlight as world leaders gather for the annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Australian Woman Accused of Spiking Strawberries With Needles
item.media:description: The strawberry contamination scare led Australian supermarkets to post warning notices like the one above in the town of Mudgee in September. Some markets stopped stocking the fruit entirely.
item.description: The tampering fueled a nationwide panic that severely hurt the industry, prompted copycat incidents and led some stores to stop stocking the fruit.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: France’s Mayors, Feeling the Pinch, Lead a Quiet Rebellion and Quit
item.media:description: “What’s the use of giving it your all, when the results just don’t come anymore,” said Louis Gentilhomme, the ex-mayor of Saint-Seine-sur-Vingeanne, who quit earlier this year.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: More than 150 rural mayors have left this year, saying they feel abandoned by the state in the face of shrinking revenues, declining populations and reforms initiated by President Emmanuel Macron.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Rockets Are Fired From Gaza Into Israel After Killing of Palestinian Fighters
item.media:description: A bus burns in Israel on Monday after it was hit in a rocket and mortar attack from the Gaza Strip.
item.description: A covert operation that apparently went awry on Sunday has been followed by retaliatory escalation, with rocket launches from Gaza and airstrikes from Israel.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Stimulus Plan or Populist Giveaway? Italy’s Budget Sets Up Clash With E.U.
item.media:description: A market in Naples, Italy. The anti-establishment Five Star Movement is looking to rally support in the relatively poor south of the country with a welfare program estimated to cost around $9 billion.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: How best to invigorate the country’s economy has reanimated a wrenching debate in Europe about whether it is better to spend or cut in the face of stagnation.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: China, After Outcry, Reinstates Ban on Rhino and Tiger Parts in Medicine
item.media:description: A market for traditional medicine ingredients in Guangzhou, China. While doctors generally prefer herbal remedies, there is a small but lucrative trade in rhino and tiger parts.
item.description: The State Council said in a rare concession that it had decided to postpone an order to undo a 25-year prohibition on the trade.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: U.S. Navy Carrier Suffers Second Aircraft Crash in Weeks
item.media:description: Two aircraft assigned to the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan have crashed in recent months, including an F/A 18 Hornet on Monday.
item.media:credit: Mass Communication Specialist 2nd Class Kaila V. Peters/United States Navy, via Associated Press
item.description: An F/A-18 Super Hornet, assigned to the U.S.S. Ronald Reagan, on Monday crashed into the sea northeast of the Philippines. The two aviators inside the plane were rescued.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Portugal Dispatch: This Town Once Feared the 10-Story Waves. Then the Extreme Surfers Showed Up.
item.media:description: For centuries, Nazaré was a traditional seaside town where Portuguese fishermen taught their children to avoid the huge waves that crashed against the nearby cliffs.
item.media:credit: Ana Brigida for The New York Times
item.description: The residents of Nazaré used to think the immense waves that broke against town’s cliffs were deadly to any who braved them. Today, those same waves have made the town a surfers’ mecca.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Canada’s Message to Teenagers: Marijuana Is Legal Now. Please Don’t Smoke It.
item.media:description: Jenny Hanley, seated in front, and her daughter Shelby Hanley, 17, left, with Kyle Johnston, 16, center, and Jared Kaye, 19, right, who live with Ms. Hanley on her family farm.
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.description: Canadian teenagers use more marijuana than youths anywhere else in the world. The government hopes legalization will change that.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Poland’s Leaders March With Far-Right Groups on Independence Day
item.media:description: A banner reading “Independence March — Death to the enemies of the homeland” in Warsaw on Sunday.
item.description: The president said the 100th anniversary of Polish independence was “for everyone.” The march included the far right and omitted opposition leaders.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Iranians Fear Medicine Shortages as U.S. Tightens Sanctions
item.media:description: The drugstore at Nikan Hospital in Tehran. Anxieties over the availability of medicine in Iran are growing.
item.description: Harsh restrictions against doing business with Iran have made it nearly impossible for pharmaceutical companies to continue working in the country.
item.dc:creator: NILO TABRIZY

item.title: Young Activists Go Missing in China, Raising Fears of Crackdown
item.media:description: Zhang Shengye has been a prominent voice in the activists’ campaign.
item.description: The Communist Party appears to be redoubling efforts to quash a movement for workers’ rights that has spread across Chinese campuses.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Alibaba’s Singles Day Sales Top $30 Billion. The Party May Not Last.
item.media:description: Alibaba’s sales on Singles Day, which gets its name from the date, Nov. 11, broke the 200 billion yuan, or $28.8 billion, mark near the end of the 24-hour shopping event on Sunday.
item.description: China’s slowing economic growth and weakening consumer sentiment pose a challenge to an e-commerce giant with world-swallowing ambitions.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Remembering the End of World War I, in Photos
item.media:description: President Trump attended a ceremony on Sunday at Suresnes American Cemetery outside Paris.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: World leaders and ordinary citizens alike commemorated the 100th anniversary of the armistice that ended World War I. Here are the best images of the day.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: How China Creates Cancer Refugees
item.description: A rural resident in China is 30 percent more likely to die after a cancer diagnosis than an urban resident. Three rural families trying to beat these odds — “cancer refugees” — share their stories of battling the disease far from home and the financial ruin it causes.

item.title: Russia Dispatch: In Russian Village Swallowed by Sand, Life’s a Beach. Just Not in a Good Way.
item.media:description: A house submerged in sand in Shoyna, Russia.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Shoyna, a fishing village in the frigid far north, is slowly vanishing under dunes that engulf entire houses. For children, home is now a giant sandbox. Adults have to “say goodbye to my high heels.”
item.dc:creator: Photographs and Text by SERGEY PONOMAREV

item.title: Rocket Lab’s Modest Launch Is Giant Leap for Small Rocket Business
item.media:description: Rocket Lab’s Electron launched from a site in New Zealand on Sunday, local time. The rocket carried seven payloads, all small satellites.
item.description: The company’s Electron rocket carried a batch of small commercial satellites from a launchpad in New Zealand, a harbinger of a major transformation to the space business.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Britain’s Equal Pay Day Highlights Gender Gap
item.media:description: In January the China editor of the BBC, Carrie Gracie, quit her job to protest unequal wages and donated backdated pay she received from the organization to a legal fund for low-income women.
item.description: Groups around the world highlight a gender gap by noting the day of the year — in Britain, it’s Nov. 10 — when women would start working without pay, relative to men’s annual earnings.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Rome Mayor Acquitted on Lying Charge, to Relief of Five Star Movement
item.media:description: “This sentence wipes away two years of political mud,” Mayor Virginia Raggi said.
item.description: The long-running corruption case had threatened both her political career and the credibility of her anti-establishment party.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Ma Jian, Exiled Chinese Novelist, Hails Appearance as Victory for Rights
item.media:description: Ma Jian, center, said the totalitarian society George Orwell predicted in “1984” had been “completely and totally” realized in China.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The temporary cancellation of his appearance at a literary festival had been seen as the latest sign of erosions of freedom in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Mexico Gave the Migrant Caravan a Warm Welcome. It Wasn’t Always This Way.
item.media:description: Central American migrants riding on the subway on Friday after leaving a temporary shelter at a stadium in Mexico City.
item.description: A caravan of Central American migrants has left Mexico City, bound for the U.S. border. The group has forced a reckoning in Mexico over the treatment of migrants.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Afghanistan Is the World’s Polio Capital. These Afghans Hope to Fix That.
item.media:description: A health care worker giving a dose of vaccine in Kandahar, Afghanistan, in August.
item.description: These Afghans Are Trying to Fix That.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED

item.title: Turkey’s President Says Recording of Khashoggi’s Killing Was Given to U.S.
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, shown on Saturday in Ankara, said Turkey had shared recordings linked to the murder of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi with Saudi Arabia, the United States and other countries.
item.description: The recordings would be another piece of evidence in the October killing of the dissident by Saudi agents in the country’s consulate in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: As Brazil’s Far Right Leader Threatens the Amazon, One Tribe Pushes Back
item.media:description: Illegal gold miners work at a mine in Posto de Vigilancia.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: “Where there is indigenous land,” newly elected President Jair Bolsonaro has said, “there is wealth underneath it.”
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: After Thousand Oaks Shooting, International Readers Question America's Gun Laws and Culture
item.media:description: A vigil held for those killed in a shooting at the Borderline Bar & Grill in Thousand Oaks, Calif.
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.description: Our international readers ask Americans to explain gun violence and share their own theories on why it is so common in the United States.
item.dc:creator: LELA MOORE

item.title: Bonhomie? C’est Fini as Trump and Macron Seek to Defuse Tension
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France welcomed President Trump at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: President Trump’s meeting with President Emmanuel Macron of France appeared far chillier than their earlier warm sessions, demonstrating how the relationship has soured.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: News Analysis: Can Europe’s Liberal Order Survive as the Memory of War Fades?
item.media:description: Tyne Cot cemetery in Belgium is the largest Commonwealth cemetery in the world. Nearly 8,400 of roughly 12,000 soldiers buried there remain unidentified.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: As leaders commemorate the end of World War I, some of the same forces that threatened democracy and peace 100 years ago are resurgent today.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: What You Need to Know About Boeing’s 737 Max
item.media:description: Boeing employees celebrate the first Max 7 coming off the production line in Renton, Wash. Since its introduction in 2017, the 737 Max series of planes has been bought by dozens of airlines.
item.description: This popular passenger jet was recently involved in the Lion Air fatal crash. If you’re worried about flying one on your next trip, here is a quick guide to the plane and the airlines that fly it.
item.dc:creator: ZACH WICHTER

item.title: A Joyous Letter Speaks of War’s End
item.media:description: Crowds along Fifth Avenue celebrated Armistice Day in November 1918.
item.description: A 100-year-old letter from a New York City police officer to one of his men overseas describes the moment the city heard that World War I was over.
item.dc:creator: JIM DWYER

item.title: Wildfires, Thousand Oaks, Elections: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Canada Letter: Americans Cast Their Ballots. The World Had Questions.
item.media:description: Sarah Lyall voting in the midterm election in Brooklyn, New York.
item.media:credit: Holly Pickett for The New York Times
item.description: Sarah Lyall, author of the Abroad in America newsletter, reflects on explaining the midterm elections to a global audience
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Tensions Ease in Gaza, Allowing Money and Fuel to Roll In
item.media:description: Since last month, new fuel deliveries have increased electricity in Gaza from just a few hours a day to as many as 12 hours.
item.description: But the relaxation of the embargo presents risks for the leaders of both Israel and Hamas, and it has been denounced by the Palestinian Authority.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Car Bombs Kill at Least 20 in Somalia’s Capital
item.media:description: Security officers fleeing the scene of an explosion in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Friday.
item.description: The Islamic extremist group the Shabab claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: What We Know About the Lion Air Flight 610 Crash
item.media:description: Indonesian rescue personnel recovered the wreckage of an engine from Lion Air Flight 610 and brought it to Tanjung Priok port in Jakarta.
item.description: The new plane’s automated systems may have played a role, but the precise cause remains unknown.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Past Tense: In Photos Unpublished for 100 Years, the Joy of War’s End on Armistice Day
item.media:description: “Men and women of all classes of society joining in uproarious demonstrations, cheering, singing and flag waving in the Place de la Concorde, Paris.” Dec. 12, 1918.
item.description: As crowds gathered in New York, Paris and London, photographers captured the public’s jubilant mood.
item.dc:creator: ALEXIS CLARK

item.title: Britain’s Brexit Endgame Is Close. Here’s How It May Play Out.
item.media:description: An anti-Brexit campaigner outside Parliament last month. Crunch time is arriving for efforts to strike a divorce with the European Union.
item.description: Prime Minister Theresa May is walking a very fine line to get a deal done. The resignation of another minister illustrated how hard it is going to be.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Justice, Italian Style: 9 Years, 13 Trials and Few Answers
item.media:description: Ilaria Cucchi with a photo of her brother Stefano. Her nine-year quest for the truth about his death in police custody has taken her on a labyrinthine trip through Italy’s justice system.
item.description: The death of her brother in police custody has turned Ilaria Cucchi into a prominent and admired rights activist. But the sprawling case continues to grind through the courts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Looking to History and Recent Events, German Leaders Defend Democracy and Pluralism
item.media:description: An exhibition at the Topography of Terror museum in Berlin shows a photograph of a burning synagogue during Kristallnacht in 1938.
item.description: On a date freighted with historic meaning, Germany’s president calls for “an enlightened patriotism,” or national pride without bigotry.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Sri Lanka President Dissolves Parliament Amid Power Struggle
item.media:description: Prime minister Mahinda Rajapaksa, center left, and president Maithripala Sirisena, center right, at a rally in Colombo on Monday.
item.media:credit: M a Pushpa Kumara/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.description: Maithripala Sirisena’s move, which critics said was illegal, deepened a two-week-old constitutional crisis over who is the legitimate prime minister of the island nation.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and VINDU GOEL

item.title: A Somber World War I Memorial in London Seeks to Finally Lay the Fallen to Rest
item.media:description: Soldiers helped lay out the 72,396 shrouded figures in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in London on Wednesday.
item.description: The display of 72,396 shrouds, dedicated to soldiers killed in France on the battlefields of the Somme, is tied to the 100th anniversary of the war’s armistice.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: At War: Remembering World War I, 100 Years Later
item.media:description: The front page of The New York Times on Nov. 11, 1918.
item.description: Nov. 11 marks 100 years since the signing of the armistice that ended World War I. Readers share how their families commemorated the centennial.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Courage and Folly of a War That Left Indelible Scars
item.media:description: An American gun crew during the Meuse-Argonne offensive in France in 1918.
item.description: During World War I, millions died, empires crumbled, nations were formed and maps were redrawn in ways that reverberate mightily a century later.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
